Let RRR be a commutative ring, I≤JI \le JI≤J be ideals of RRR. If RRR is JJJ-adically complete, is it also III-adically complete? Equivalently, is lim⁡⟵R/In→lim⁡⟵R/Jn\lim\limits_\longleftarrow R / I ^ n \to \lim\limits_\longleftarrow R / J ^ n⟵lim​R/In→⟵lim​R/Jn injective?

It is true when III is finitely generated, but I don't have a proof nor a counterexample when III is not fg. I am attaching my proof in the fg case below in case someone can strengthen (or simplify) it.

Proof

Let x∈lim⁡⟵R/Inx \in \lim\limits_\longleftarrow R / I ^ nx∈⟵lim​R/In. We can write xxx as x=∑i=0∞xix = \sum_{i = 0}^\infty x_ix=∑i=0∞​xi​ with xi∈Iix_i \in I ^ ixi​∈Ii.
Suppose the image of xxx in lim⁡⟵R/Jn\lim\limits_\longleftarrow R / J ^ n⟵lim​R/Jn is zero.
We want to show that xxx is zero in lim⁡⟵R/In\lim\limits_\longleftarrow R / I ^ n⟵lim​R/In, i.e. ∑i=0n−1xi∈In\sum_{i = 0}^{n-1} x_i \in I ^ n∑i=0n−1​xi​∈In for all nnn.
Since III is fg, so is InI^nIn. Suppose InI^nIn is generated by {ak}\{a_k\}{ak​}.
We can write xn+i∈In+ix_{n + i} \in I^{n + i}xn+i​∈In+i as xn+i=∑kakyi,kx_{n + i} = \sum_k a_k y_{i, k}xn+i​=∑k​ak​yi,k​ with yi,k∈Iiy_{i, k} \in I ^ iyi,k​∈Ii.
Then yk:=∑i=0∞yi,ky_k := \sum_{i = 0}^\infty y_{i, k}yk​:=∑i=0∞​yi,k​ is a well defined element in RRR because it is JJJ-adically complete, and ∑i=0n−1xi+∑kakyk=0\sum_{i = 0}^{n - 1} x_i + \sum_k a_k y_k = 0∑i=0n−1​xi​+∑k​ak​yk​=0 as elements of RRR because its image in lim⁡⟵R/Jn\lim\limits_\longleftarrow R / J ^ n⟵lim​R/Jn is equal to the image of xxx, which is zero.

Since ∑kakyk∈In\sum_k a_k y_k \in I ^ n∑k​ak​yk​∈In, this implies ∑i=0n−1xi∈In\sum_{i = 0}^{n - 1} x_i \in I ^ n∑i=0n−1​xi​∈In and we're done.
I don't know about your "equivalently" claim but if R is the integers of Qpbar, J is the maximal ideal and I=0 then the map isn't injective
But it's assumed that R is J-adically complete.

I think the "equivalently" means if you have two functions fff and ggg such that f∘gf\circ gf∘g is bijective, then ggg is bijective iff fff is injective. Here g:R→lim⁡⟵R/Ing:R\to\lim\limits_\longleftarrow R / I ^ ng:R→⟵lim​R/In and f:lim⁡⟵R/In→lim⁡⟵R/Jnf:\lim\limits_\longleftarrow R / I ^ n\to\lim\limits_\longleftarrow R / J ^ nf:⟵lim​R/In→⟵lim​R/Jn.

If there's some natural NNN such that JN⊆IJ^N\subseteq IJN⊆I then I bet you're fine, and JJJ-adic completeness implies that the intersection of JnJ^nJn is 0 so III can't be strictly smaller than this intersection, so perhaps the place to look for a counterexample is R0=R[X1,X2,X3,…]R_0=\R[X_1,X_2,X_3,\ldots]R0​=R[X1​,X2​,X3​,…], J0=(X1,X2,X3,…)J_0=(X_1,X_2,X_3,\ldots)J0​=(X1​,X2​,X3​,…), I0=(X1,X22,X33,…)I_0=(X_1,X_2^2,X_3^3,\ldots)I0​=(X1​,X22​,X33​,…) and then RRR is the J0J_0J0​-adic completion of R0R_0R0​ and I,JI,JI,J are the images of I0,J0I_0,J_0I0​,J0​. If this isn't a counterexample then maybe the proof that it isn't a counterexample will turn into a proof that it's true in general?
Oh no it seems deeper than this. stacks#05JA shows that I can't just blithely complete and expect that the result is complete :-/

Exactly. It is well known that « completion » of rings are not well-behaved outside of the finitely generated case, and I have the impression that mathematicians try to flee away of these questions, or approach them differently, eg, via condensed sets, to get a better definition of complete, with better theorems.
